data.title: Cats race
data.solution:
<?php
fscanf(STDIN, "%d %d", $w, $h);
fscanf(STDIN, "%d %d %d %d %d %d", $fx, $fy, $tx, $ty, $bx, $by);

$matrix = [];
for ($i = 0; $i < $h; $i++)
{
    $wallRow = stream_get_line(STDIN, $w + 1, "\n");
    $matrix[] = str_split($wallRow);
}

$distMatrix[$by][$bx] = 0;
exploreCellsFrom($bx, $by);

if ($distMatrix[$fy][$fx] == $distMatrix[$ty][$tx]) echo $distMatrix[$fy][$fx] . " Tie";
else echo $distMatrix[$fy][$fx] < $distMatrix[$ty][$tx] ? $distMatrix[$fy][$fx] . " Flash" : $distMatrix[$ty][$tx] . " Tornade";

function exploreCellsFrom($x, $y) {
    global $distMatrix, $w, $h, $matrix;
    $cellsToExplore = [
        $y+2 < $h ? [$x, $y+2] : null,
        $y+1 < $h ? [$x, $y+1] : null,
        $y+1 < $h && $x+1 < $w ? [$x+1, $y+1] : null,
        $y-2 >= 0 ? [$x, $y-2] : null,
        $y-1 >= 0 ? [$x, $y-1] : null,
        $y-1 >= 0 && $x-1 >= 0 ? [$x-1, $y-1] : null,
        $x+2 < $w ? [$x+2, $y] : null,
        $x+1 < $w ? [$x+1, $y] : null,
        $x+1 < $w && $y-1 >= 0 ? [$x+1, $y-1] : null,
        $x-2 >= 0 ? [$x-2, $y] : null,
        $x-1 >= 0 ? [$x-1, $y] : null,
        $x-1 >= 0 && $y+1 < $h ? [$x-1, $y+1] : null,
    ];

    foreach ($cellsToExplore as $cell) {
        if ($cell && $matrix[$cell[1]][$cell[0]] != '#' && (!isset($distMatrix[$cell[1]][$cell[0]]) || $distMatrix[$cell[1]][$cell[0]] > $distMatrix[$y][$x] + 1)) {
            $distMatrix[$cell[1]][$cell[0]] = $distMatrix[$y][$x] + 1;
            exploreCellsFrom($cell[0], $cell[1]);
        }
    }
}
?>
data.statement:
It's feeding time for two cats named {{Flash}} and {{Tornade}} ! The issue is that, to eat, they need to reach their food bowl which can be placed on one of the many platforms fixed to the wall.
The goal is to find out <<which one of them will be first to reach it with the less moves possible>>. If both cats made <<the same number of moves to reach their food, it's a {{Tie}}>> !

The wall is represented in 2D as a matrix of [[h]] rows and [[w]] columns.
({{0, 0}}) is the top left.
([[w]]{{- 1}}, [[h]]{{- 1}}) is the bottom right.
<<The last row of the matrix being the floor>>.
Each cell of the matrix contains either :
{{_}} an underscore character representing a floor cell. Last row of the matrix will always contain only underscores.
{{-}} a hyphen character representing a platform.
{{#}} a hash character representing an empty cell on the wall where cats can't jump to.
{{B}} representing the food bowl.

The interesting part is that cats are great jumpers, so <<they are able, with a single jump, to reach a platform diagonally or at most two cells away in a straight direction from their position>>.
Here is an example of representation of their jump range, C being a cat, + being his reachable cells :
~~+~~
~+++~
++C++
~+++~
~~+~~

Any kind of move (short or long jump, on the floor or to a platform) <<counts as one single move>>.

testCases.title: Validator Food is on the floor

data.constraints: Both cats will always have starting positions from the floor so <<[[fy]] and [[ty]] inputs are always initialized with [[h]]{{-1}} value>>.

data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1 :>> Two integers [[w]] and [[h]] representing the width and height of the wall.
<<Line 2 :>> Six integers [[fx]] [[fy]] [[tx]] [[ty]] [[bx]] [[by]].
([[fx]], [[fy]]) representing the starting position of Flash.
([[tx]], [[ty]]) representing the starting position of Tornade.
([[bx]], [[by]]) representing the position of the food bowl.
<<[[h]] next lines :>> Sequence of string characters representing a row of the wall.
data.outputDescription: A line containing <<the lowest number of moves needed to reach the food bowl>>, followed by <<a space>>, and either <<the name of the cat who reached it first>> or {{Tie}} if both cats needed to make the same number of moves.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

It's feeding time for two cats named Flash and Tornade ! The issue is that, to eat, they need to reach their food bowl which can be placed on one of the many platforms fixed to the wall.
The goal is to find out which one of them will be first to reach it with the less moves possible. If both cats made the same number of moves to reach their food, it's a Tie !

The wall is represented in 2D as a matrix of h rows and w columns.
(0, 0) is the top left.
(w- 1, h- 1) is the bottom right.
The last row of the matrix being the floor.
Each cell of the matrix contains either :
_ an underscore character representing a floor cell. Last row of the matrix will always contain only underscores.
- a hyphen character representing a platform.
# a hash character representing an empty cell on the wall where cats can't jump to.
B representing the food bowl.

The interesting part is that cats are great jumpers, so they are able, with a single jump, to reach a platform diagonally or at most two cells away in a straight direction from their position.
Here is an example of representation of their jump range, C being a cat, + being his reachable cells :
~~+~~
~+++~
++C++
~+++~
~~+~~

Any kind of move (short or long jump, on the floor or to a platform) counts as one single move.
Input
Line 1 : Two integers w and h representing the width and height of the wall.
Line 2 : Six integers fx fy tx ty bx by.
(fx, fy) representing the starting position of Flash.
(tx, ty) representing the starting position of Tornade.
(bx, by) representing the position of the food bowl.
h next lines : Sequence of string characters representing a row of the wall.
Output
A line containing the lowest number of moves needed to reach the food bowl, followed by a space, and either the name of the cat who reached it first or Tie if both cats needed to make the same number of moves.
Constraints
Both cats will always have starting positions from the floor so fy and ty inputs are always initialized with h-1 value.
Example
Input
3 3
0 2 2 2 0 1
---
B-#
___
Output
1 Flash
